title: Solar arrays coming to Metro Transit buildings

(Staff photo: Bill Klotz) Solar arrays coming to Metro Transit buildings By: Brian Johnson September 29, 2015 4:24 pm 0 
Metro Transit plans to install rooftop solar panels on a half-dozen of its buildings in the Twin Cities next year, an initiative that aims to reduce energy costs and bolster the agency’s green credentials. 
The arrays will crank out a combined 4.7 megawatts of solar power and help save an estimated $4 million in energy costs over 25 years, Metro Transit said. 
“Conserving resources and protecting the environment is what transit is all about,” General Manager Brian Lamb said in a statement. “Our passengers are doing their part to reduce their environmental impact, and we want to match that commitment by putting sustainability at the forefront of everything we do.” 
Panels will be installed at bus garages in Minneapolis, Bloomington and St. Paul, as well as a bus maintenance facility in St. Paul and a Blue Line light rail maintenance building in Minneapolis, according to Metro Transit. 
Drew Kerr, a Metro Transit spokesman, said the installation should begin early next year and be completed by the end of 2016. 
“We should be getting energy from the panels before the end of the calendar year next year,” Kerr said. 
Metro Transit said that its rooftop arrays — combined with a subscription to community solar gardens — will account for about 16 percent of its expected 2016 electrical use. About 71 percent of Metro Transit’s electrical usage in 2016 will go toward light rail operations. 
Under a plan approved by the Metropolitan Council last week, Metro Transit will purchase energy produced by the new solar arrays from Solar City, a California-based solar provider with clients across the country. 
Solar City will pay for the equipment and its installation. Under the agreement, Metro Transit will purchase the electricity at a locked rate for 25 years. 
Solar arrays are on the rise in Minnesota. 
By its latest count, the Minnesota Department of Commerce estimates the state has about 25 megawatts of solar capacity overall, said Ross Corson, communications director for the department. 
Corson said capacity stood at about 20 megawatts last fall. 
Metro Transit currently has 40-kilowatt solar arrays on a new park-and-ride facility at the northwest corner of Highway 610 and Noble Parkway in Brooklyn Park, and on a light rail support facility at Hiawatha Avenue and East 24th Street in Minneapolis. 
Several bus shelters also tap into solar power. 
Metro Transit estimates it saved about $22.5 million between 2009 and 2014 as a result of its overall conservation efforts, which include LED lighting and efficient HVAC systems in its buildings, and the use of hybrid buses. 
Hybrids represent about 15 percent of the total bus fleet. 
The new solar installations are planned for these buildings: Fred T. Heywood office building and garage, 560 Sixth Ave. N., Minneapolis; East Metro Transit facility, 800 Mississippi St., St. Paul; Nicollet Garage, 10 W. 32nd St., Minneapolis; South Garage, 2100 MTC Road, Bloomington; Overhaul Base, 515 N. Cleveland Ave., St. Paul, and Minneapolis Light Rail Operations and Maintenance facility, 1810 E. Franklin Ave. Share this:
